I was able to reproduce this easily by launching the JUnit sample AllTests. However, debugging to 
the point where the exception is thrown shows that the problem isn't coming from our code. The 
JUnit launch delegate is making calls to the Platform which end up throwing the exception. I can't 
tell if it's a JUnit or a Platform Core problem.

I figured this is related to the fact I just migrated org.eclipse.jdt.core.* 
projects to use the PDE container on their classpath.
When launching some compiler Junit tests, I used to be able to simply run
them as Junit tests. Since I converted to use the PDE container, I have to 
launch them using the plugin test launcher. Is this normal ? None of these test 
actually need to run Eclipse (compiler is not using Eclipse at all).

This feels like a regression to me.

CC'ed Darin who mentionned:

We recently released a fix such that regular Java Applications honor PDE 
containers. However it went into the Feb 3 build - can you point me at the 
test cases?
Also see bug 46418

I can reproduce this. I think it is an OS limitation on the command line

is as follows. However, I'm not sure how to configure this.

Moving to platform-debug, any insight appreciated :-)

Maybe using env variables to factor common path prefixes, would get you in a 
better position ?

Darin, the ECLIPSE_HOME classpath variable, although not used/needed by PDE 
anymore because of classpath containers, is still initialized correctly by 
us.  Its value would be the correct prefix for paths to all the external 
plugin JARs being referenced.

A project resolved from a container is further resolved to its entire 
buildpath - which we do for each project in a container. This can cause many 
duplicate classpath entries to appear. I have modified our code to remove 
duplicate classpath entries, which appears to make things work better. (There 
is still an issue of how a project should be resolved, but there is a 
different bug open for that - bug 52357)
This fixes the problem for me (it creates a small enough command line).
Please verify, Luc. Changes in JavaRuntime.

I can't get the AllTests example from JUnit to run. I get the same error that
Jared report in comment 2.
May be it's an other problem ...

The problem you and Jared have found is a separate bug (which I can't seem to 
reproduce). Could you open a new bug report for it? It looks like it should 
live/start in JDT-UI (JUnit).

The problem I fixed (and that Philippe is having) has to do with using 
the "PDE Required Plug-ins" container on the classpath. Try to run a simple 
Hello World program from a plug-in, and ensure that the config's classpath has 
the PDE "Plugin Depenencies" container on its runtime classpath (for example, 
create a simple program in the Java debug tests).
*** Bug 52357 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Verified.
I cannot reproducet the other problem anymore.
